creator: dgoyal@oatsystems.com
text:
On all the deletes and creates of folders, ant throws an error that it could 
not do that. You run it next time, it passes that step and gets stuck on next. 
Finally, after multiple runs, ant builds successfully. If I run a program like 
FileMon, it slows down the systems, but this time ant builds successfully in 
first time. It seems to me that it is some kind of multiple thread problem. If 
you slow system down, threads sync properly, otherwise in a fast system they 
scramble up.

creator: peter.reilly@corvil.com
text:
Please try ant 1.6.1.
There is a timing issue with recursive deletion of directories
on windows/dos. A work-around has been placed
in the delete task.

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text:
Note:  The workaround does help but it still may not be entirely foolproof.  
All in all, this is really a Java bug.

Is there any patch for this problem? Our official ant version is 1.5.4. I am 
afraid if I switch to 1.6.1, it may break something else or may not be 
compatible with the work my colleagues are doing using 1.5.4.
creator: dgoyal@oatsystems.com

text: I pressed a wrong option. I would still like to have more information.
creator: dgoyal@oatsystems.com

text:
The fix was made to org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.Delete .  You could try 
patching just this class, but which is the lesser of two evils--running a 
patched version or upgrading to a newer release?  I can only think of one 
feature offhand that is an ACCEPTED incompatibility from 1.5.4 to 1.6.x, so if 
you upgrade to 1.6.1 and something breaks, it needs to be reported anyway...
